lifting company in France, it's in the

It's got a fleet of around 600 cranes
and they are in this distinctive yellow and

59.04.text:
This model from WSI is a limited
edition in the colors of Mediaco.

63.22.text:
It is a Tadano ATF 70G and it comes in a
standard

69.42.text:
Going inside there are the usual pair
of expanded polystyrene trays and

74.17.text:
The trays are not marked top and bottom and
we're out of luck because we have opened it

77.48.text: upside down but we will flip it over

79.52.text: and there are the parts sitting in the tray.

82.16.text:
Also included with the model is a very
good instruction manual.

85.33.text:
It has got a full parts list, and it has got all the
instructions you need for displaying the

90.65.text: or setting it up and using it as a crane.

93.57.text:
It also shows you how to use the
optional fly jib.

105.14.text:
For the initial assembly we will just put
the crane in road going formation

108.74.text:
and the first thing is this crane can
carry its own counterweight,

112.22.text:
and it carries it on the middle of the
carrier deck in order to even out the

118.01.text:
The hook is already reeved in the
factory so the only other thing to do is

121.61.text: to attach the optional fly jib.

124.39.text:
That gets pinned in position on the side
but you might have to fiddle to get the pin in

135.00.text:
The underside is fairly detailed with a
ladder under the cab,

138.27.text: and drive shafts to the rear three axles.

141.34.text:
The cab looks good with decent lights
and mirrors and if we compare it to the

145.19.text:
real crane the model has an accurate
fleet number

149.46.text:
One of the really nice tiny details
is the detailed instrument console

154.09.text:
and the same high standard is also true
of the crane cab.

158.65.text:
The graphics are very sharp and that includes those
on the very detailed outriggers.

163.25.text:
Other parts of the crane body are detailed
too and include plenty of hydraulic

168.93.text:
The detailing of the boom is also
accurate to the real crane and that includes

172.35.text: the graphics on the top surface.

175.07.text:
There are also graphics on the inner boom
sections and they look really good.

179.07.text:
The lattice fly jib is a decent metal
part as is the hook,

182.33.text:
and there is a hoist cut-out safety chain
which is a nice detail.

191.50.text:
Starting underneath the axles are
engineered well with

194.66.text:
each of them having independent sprung
suspension.

198.53.text:
All axles also have steering with the
rear three being notched,

202.60.text:
but that does mean that they can be
set to hold a pose.

206.69.text:
Driving the Tadano along it motors pretty
well

210.12.text:
so let's now set the steering and see
what it's like

214.87.text:
and that works well because the axles
hold their position

220.11.text:
Anyway after driving around the table
top a couple of times we arrive on site so

226.32.text:
The metal outrigger beams are single
stage and pull out easily,

229.37.text:
and then you can wind down the Pads.  Also
included with the model are some plastic

235.58.text:
If you want you can insert tiny clips to
look the pads in place,

239.04.text:
and the outrigger arrangement is strong
enough to support the model 'wheels-free'.

243.76.text:
So its hooks away' and let's do what we
like to do

246.74.text:
and that is raise our boom!   The main ram
has a metal jacket

250.78.text: and you look the extension with a key.

Now the real crane would swing
around and pick up its own counterweight

258.95.text:
but in the alternative universe that is
Cranes Etc,

262.06.text: a giant hand does the trick.

264.77.text:
You have to clip it right up to make
sure the crane can rotate properly,

268.12.text:
and next we will add an included weight on to the
hook which puts tension into the ropes,

273.64.text:
and then by inserting another key into
the winch drum we can drive the crane.

277.79.text:
The drum relies on friction as a break
but it will hold

283.40.text:
Next we can begin to extend the boom by

These work smoothly enough and they lock

There are a couple of nice features on

310.61.text:
and these are good because they stay open
and they let you see some detailed

317.46.text:
You know, at Cranes Etc we always like to

We will open it up to its full length and
and it then pins into position,

and after that we can then pin it to the

But one thing you might find is that

We have disconnected the hook already and the
other thing we can do is to disconnect

343.81.text:
and then we can raise the guide pulley on

The supplied hook is not ideal for running

351.82.text:
but here we've attached it as a single line

356.05.text: can adjust the offset angle of the jib.

359.14.text:
So now it's time for a 'Dim Check' and let's

363.42.text:
and it is about 36 inches or 90

367.29.text:
and about 4 feet or 120 centimetres to

the Cranes Etc team just

400.03.text:
This is another very high quality crane
model from WSI,

403.87.text:
and it is certainly a very good looking one

409.84.text:
The detail level on the model is very
